HaliteEncrustedCobbleDeadSea.JPG)](/wiki/File:HaliteEncrustedCobbleDeadSea.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:HaliteEncrustedCobbleDeadSea.JPG "Enlarge")

Cobble encrusted with [halite](/wiki/Halite "Halite") evaporated from the
[Dead Sea](/wiki/Dead_Sea "Dead Sea"), Israel

**Evaporite** ( [/ɪˈvæpəraɪt/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")) is
the term for a water-soluble [mineral](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral")
[sediment](/wiki/Sedimentary_rock "Sedimentary rock") that results from
concentration and [crystallization](/wiki/Crystallization "Crystallization")
by [evaporation](/wiki/Evaporation "Evaporation") from an aqueous solution.[1]
There are two types of evaporite deposits: marine, which can also be described
as ocean deposits, and non-marine, which are found in standing bodies of water
such as lakes. Evaporites are considered [sedimentary
rocks](/wiki/Sedimentary_rock "Sedimentary rock") and are formed by chemical
sediments.

## Formation of evaporite
rocks[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evaporite&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section:
Formation of evaporite rocks")]

Although all water bodies on the surface and in aquifers contain dissolved
salts, the water must evaporate into the atmosphere for the minerals to
precipitate. For this to happen, the water body must enter a restricted
environment where water input into this environment remains below the net rate
of evaporation. This is usually an [arid](/wiki/Arid "Arid") environment with
a small basin fed by a limited input of water. When evaporation occurs, the
remaining water is enriched in salts, and they precipitate when the water
becomes supersaturated.

## Evaporite depositional
environments[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evaporite&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Evaporite depositional environments")]

### Marine
evaporites[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evaporite&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Marine evaporites")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Anhydrite_HMNH1.jpg/220px-
Anhydrite_HMNH1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Anhydrite_HMNH1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Anhydrite_HMNH1.jpg "Enlarge")

Anhydrite

Marine evaporites tend to have thicker deposits and are usually the focus of
more extensive research.[2] They also have a system of evaporation. When
scientists evaporate ocean water in a laboratory, the minerals are deposited
in a defined order that was first demonstrated by Usiglio in 1884.[2] The
first phase of the experiment begins when about 50% of the original water
depth remains. At this point, minor [carbonates](/wiki/Carbonate "Carbonate")
begin to form.[2] The next phase in the sequence comes when the experiment is
left with about 20% of its original level. At this point, the mineral
[gypsum](/wiki/Gypsum "Gypsum") begins to form, which is then followed by
[halite](/wiki/Halite "Halite") at 10%,[2] excluding carbonate minerals that
tend not to be evaporites. The most common minerals that are generally
considered to be the most representative of marine evaporites are
[calcite](/wiki/Calcite "Calcite"), [gypsum](/wiki/Gypsum "Gypsum") and
[anhydrite](/wiki/Anhydrite "Anhydrite"), [halite](/wiki/Halite "Halite"),
[sylvite](/wiki/Sylvite "Sylvite"), [carnallite](/wiki/Carnallite
"Carnallite"), [langbeinite](/wiki/Langbeinite "Langbeinite"),
[polyhalite](/wiki/Polyhalite "Polyhalite"), and [kainite](/wiki/Kainite
"Kainite"). [Kieserite](/wiki/Kieserite "Kieserite") (MgSO4) may also be
included, which often will make up less than four percent of the overall
content.[2] However, there are approximately 80 different minerals that have
been reported found in evaporite deposits (Stewart,1963;Warren,1999), though
only about a dozen are common enough to be considered important rock
formers.[2]

### Non-marine
evaporites[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evaporite&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Non-marine evaporites")]

Non-marine evaporites are usually composed of minerals that are not common in
marine environments because in general the water from which non-marine
evaporite precipitates has proportions of chemical elements different from
those found in the marine environments.[2] Common minerals that are found in
these deposits include [blödite](/wiki/Bl%C3%B6dite "Blödite"),
[borax](/wiki/Borax "Borax"), [epsomite](/wiki/Epsomite "Epsomite"),
[gaylussite](/wiki/Gaylussite "Gaylussite"), [glauberite](/wiki/Glauberite
"Glauberite"), [mirabilite](/wiki/Mirabilite "Mirabilite"),
[thenardite](/wiki/Thenardite "Thenardite") and [trona](/wiki/Trona "Trona").
Non-marine deposits may also contain halite, gypsum, and anhydrite, and may in
some cases even be dominated by these minerals, although they did not come
from ocean deposits. This, however, does not make non-marine deposits any less
important; these deposits often help to paint a picture into past Earth
climates. Some particular deposits even show important tectonic and climatic
changes. These deposits also may contain important minerals that help in
today's economy.[3] Thick non-marine deposits that accumulate tend to form
where evaporation rates will exceed the inflow rate, and where there is
sufficient soluble supplies. The inflow also has to occur in a closed basin,
or one with restricted outflow, so that the sediment has time to pool and form
in a lake or other standing body of water.[3] Primary examples of this are
called "saline lake deposits".[3] Saline lakes includes things such as
perennial lakes, which are lakes that are there year-round, playa lakes, which
are lakes that appear only during certain seasons, or any other terms that are
used to define places that hold standing bodies of water intermittently or
year-round. Examples of modern non-marine depositional environments include
the [Great Salt Lake](/wiki/Great_Salt_Lake "Great Salt Lake") in Utah and the
[Dead Sea](/wiki/Dead_Sea "Dead Sea"), which lies between Jordan and Israel.

Evaporite [depositional
environments](/wiki/Sedimentary_depositional_environment "Sedimentary
depositional environment") that meet the above conditions include:

  * [Graben](/wiki/Graben "Graben") areas and [half-grabens](/wiki/Half-graben "Half-graben") within continental [rift](/wiki/Rift_\(geology\) "Rift \(geology\)") environments fed by limited riverine drainage, usually in subtropical or tropical environments 
    * Example environments at the present that match this is the [Denakil Depression](/wiki/Denakil_Depression "Denakil Depression"), Ethiopia; [Death Valley](/wiki/Death_Valley "Death Valley"), [California](/wiki/California "California")
  * Graben environments in oceanic rift environments fed by limited oceanic input, leading to eventual isolation and evaporation 
    * Examples include the Red Sea, and the [Dead Sea](/wiki/Dead_Sea "Dead Sea") in Jordan and Israel
  * Internal drainage basins in arid to semi-arid temperate to tropical environments fed by ephemeral drainage 
    * Example environments at the present include the [Simpson Desert](/wiki/Simpson_Desert "Simpson Desert"), [Western Australia](/wiki/Western_Australia "Western Australia"), the [Great Salt Lake](/wiki/Great_Salt_Lake "Great Salt Lake") in [Utah](/wiki/Utah "Utah")
  * Non-basin areas fed exclusively by groundwater seepage from artesian waters 
    * Example environments include the seep-mounds of the Victoria Desert, fed by the [Great Artesian Basin](/wiki/Great_Artesian_Basin "Great Artesian Basin"), Australia
  * Restricted coastal plains in regressive sea environments 
    * Examples include the [sabkha](/wiki/Sabkha "Sabkha") deposits of Iran, Saudi Arabia, and the Red Sea; the [Garabogazköl](/wiki/Garabogazk%C3%B6l "Garabogazköl") of the [Caspian Sea](/wiki/Caspian_Sea "Caspian Sea")
  * Drainage basins feeding into extremely arid environments 
    * Examples include the Chilean deserts, certain parts of the [Sahara](/wiki/Sahara "Sahara"), and the [Namib](/wiki/Namib "Namib")

The most significant known evaporite depositions happened during the
[Messinian salinity crisis](/wiki/Messinian_salinity_crisis "Messinian
salinity crisis") in the basin of the [Mediterranean](/wiki/Mediterranean
"Mediterranean").

## Evaporitic
formations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evaporite&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Evaporitic formations")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/SaltCrystalCasts.JPG/220px-
SaltCrystalCasts.JPG)](/wiki/File:SaltCrystalCasts.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:SaltCrystalCasts.JPG "Enlarge")

Hopper crystal cast of [halite](/wiki/Halite "Halite") in a
[Jurassic](/wiki/Jurassic "Jurassic") rock, Carmel Formation, southwestern
Utah

Evaporite formations need not be composed entirely of [halite](/wiki/Halite
"Halite") salt. In fact, most evaporite formations do not contain more than a
few percent of evaporite minerals, the remainder being composed of the more
typical [detrital](/wiki/Detrital "Detrital") [clastic](/wiki/Clastic
"Clastic") rocks and [carbonates](/wiki/Carbonate "Carbonate"). Examples of
evaporite formations include occurrences of evaporite sulfur in Eastern Europe
and West Asia.[4]

For a formation to be recognised as evaporitic it may simply require
recognition of halite [pseudomorphs](/wiki/Pseudomorph "Pseudomorph"),
sequences composed of some proportion of evaporite minerals, and recognition
of mud crack textures or other [textures](/wiki/Rock_microstructure "Rock
microstructure").

## Economic importance of
evaporites[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evaporite&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Economic importance of evaporites")]

Evaporites are important economically because of their mineralogy, their
physical properties in-situ, and their behaviour within the subsurface.

Evaporite minerals, especially nitrate minerals, are economically important in
Peru and Chile. Nitrate minerals are often mined for use in the production on
[fertilizer](/wiki/Fertilizer "Fertilizer") and [explosives](/wiki/Explosive
"Explosive").

Thick halite deposits are expected to become an important location for the
disposal of [nuclear waste](/wiki/Nuclear_waste "Nuclear waste") because of
their geologic stability, predictable engineering and physical behaviour, and
imperviousness to groundwater.

Halite formations are famous for their ability to form [diapirs](/wiki/Diapir
"Diapir"), which produce ideal locations for trapping
[petroleum](/wiki/Petroleum "Petroleum") deposits.

Halite deposits are often mined for use as [salt](/wiki/Salt "Salt").

## Major groups of evaporite
minerals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Evaporite&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Major groups of evaporite minerals")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Calcite-k270c.jpg/220px-
Calcite-k270c.jpg)](/wiki/File:Calcite-k270c.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Calcite-k270c.jpg "Enlarge")

Calcite

This is a chart that shows minerals that form the marine evaporite rocks, they
are usually the most common minerals that appear in this kind of deposit.

Mineral class | Mineral name | Chemical Composition  
---|---|---  
Chlorides | Halite Sylvite Carnallite Kainite | NaCl KCl KMgCl3 * 6H2O KMg(SO4)Cl * 3H2O  
Sulfates | Anhydrite Gypsum Kieserite Langbeinite Polyhalite | CaSO4 CaSO4 * 2H2O MgSO4 * H2O K2Mg2(SO4)3 K2Ca2Mg(SO4)6 * H2O  
Carbonates | Dolomite Calcite Magnesite | CaMg(CO3)2 CaCO3 MgCO3  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Hanksite.JPG/220px-
Hanksite.JPG)](/wiki/File:Hanksite.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Hanksite.JPG "Enlarge")

[Hanksite](/wiki/Hanksite "Hanksite"), Na22K(SO4)9(CO3)2Cl, one of the few
minerals that is both a carbonate and a sulfate

  * [Halides](/wiki/Halide_mineral "Halide mineral"): [halite](/wiki/Halite "Halite"), [sylvite](/wiki/Sylvite "Sylvite") (KCl), and [fluorite](/wiki/Fluorite "Fluorite")
  * [Sulfates](/wiki/Sulfate_mineral "Sulfate mineral"): such as [gypsum](/wiki/Gypsum "Gypsum"), [barite](/wiki/Barite "Barite"), and [anhydrite](/wiki/Anhydrite "Anhydrite")
  * [Nitrates](/wiki/Nitrate_mineral "Nitrate mineral"): [nitratine](/wiki/Nitratine "Nitratine") (soda niter) and [niter](/wiki/Niter "Niter")
  * [Borates](/wiki/Borate_mineral "Borate mineral"): typically found in arid-salt-lake deposits plentiful in the southwestern [US](/wiki/United_States "United States"). A common borate is [borax](/wiki/Borax "Borax"), which has been used in [soaps](/wiki/Soap "Soap") as a [surfactant](/wiki/Surfactant "Surfactant").
  * [Carbonates](/wiki/Carbonate_mineral "Carbonate mineral"): such as [trona](/wiki/Trona "Trona"), formed in inland brine lakes. 
    * Some evaporite minerals, such as [Hanksite](/wiki/Hanksite "Hanksite"), are from multiple groups.

Evaporite minerals start to [precipitate](/wiki/Precipitation_\(chemistry\)
"Precipitation \(chemistry\)") when their concentration in water reaches such
a level that they can no longer exist as [solutes](/wiki/Solution "Solution").

The minerals precipitate out of solution in the reverse order of their
solubilities, such that the order of precipitation from sea water is:

  1. [Calcite](/wiki/Calcite "Calcite") (CaCO3) and [dolomite](/wiki/Dolomite "Dolomite") (CaMg(CO3)2)
  2. Gypsum (CaSO4-2H2O) and anhydrite (CaSO4).
  3. Halite (i.e. common salt, NaCl)
  4. [Potassium](/wiki/Potassium "Potassium") and [magnesium](/wiki/Magnesium "Magnesium") salts

The abundance of rocks formed by seawater precipitation is in the same order
as the precipitation given above. Thus, [limestone](/wiki/Limestone
"Limestone") ([calcite](/wiki/Calcite "Calcite")) and
[dolomite](/wiki/Dolomite "Dolomite") are more common than
[gypsum](/wiki/Gypsum "Gypsum"), which is more common than
[halite](/wiki/Halite "Halite"), which is more common than
[potassium](/wiki/Potassium "Potassium") and [magnesium](/wiki/Magnesium
"Magnesium") salts.

Evaporites can also be easily
[recrystallized](/wiki/Recrystallization_\(chemistry\) "Recrystallization
\(chemistry\)") in laboratories in order to investigate the conditions and
characteristics of their formation.
